Sampling_method: Pitfall traps
IUCN_threat_category_1: 8 Invasive & other problematic species, genes & diseases
Treatment: Invasive plant (Spotted knapweed - Centaurea maculosa) present
Control: Invasive plant (Spotted knapweed - Centaurea maculosa) absent
Notes: 1) Location was a bit weird. Gave locations of 6 sites in UTM eastings and northings. Used https://www.distancelatlong.com/latlong/convert-utm-to-latlong/#:~:text=To%20get%20accurate%20Lat%20Long,moving%20mouse%20on%20below%20map.&text=Copy%20and%20paste%20the%20html,website%20or%20blog%20to%20share. to convert to lat/lon. Had to find out the 'zone' that I was looking in. 4 points worked, last 2 were weird. I just selected point in middle of the 4 that were correct. 2) Sample size not clear. They had 3 invaded and 3 univaded sites (which is what I've gone with here). But per site, there were 4 transects. Each transect had 13 pitfall traps. And they sampled 4 times in 1999, and 4 times in 2000.

Author: Loomis, J.D. and Cameron, G.N.
Title: Impact of the invasive shrub Amur honeysuckle (Lonicera maackii) on shrub-layer insects in a deciduous forest in the eastern United States
Sampling_method: Collection cloths
IUCN_threat_category_1: 8 Invasive & other problematic species, genes & diseases
Treatment: Invasive plant (Lonicera maackii - Amur honeysuckle) present
Control: Invasive plant (Lonicera maackii - Amur honeysuckle) absent
Notes: Gave co-ordinates for each of the 10 sites. I chose site in middle of all the sites to use as the co-ords here. Collection cloths were placed beneath vegetation in each 3-m2 plot (one invaded, one univaded site per each of the 10 plots), and then surface area of all vegetation in the shrub layer, including foliage and stem/trunk bark, was saturated with insecticides. Plants were undisturbed for 20 min after insecticide application to allow insects to fall onto collection cloths, and then vegetation was lightly hit with a beating stick (length 61 cm, diameter 2.54 cm) or shaken by hand to dislodge any remaining insects.

Author: Ellis, LM and Molles, MC and Crawford, CS and Heinzelmann, F
Title: Surface-active arthropod communities in native and exotic riparian vegetation in the middle Rio Grande Valley, New Mexico
Sampling_method: Pitfall traps
IUCN_threat_category_1: 8 Invasive & other problematic species, genes & diseases
Treatment: Invasive plant (Taramix genus - Saltcedar) present
Control: Invasive plant (Taramix genus - Saltcedar) absent/Cottonwood dominated forest
Notes: No exact co-ordinates given in paper. Took co-ordinates of Bosque del Apache National Wildlife Refuse as it is placed on Google Maps. This is roughly in the middle of the 4 sites. Data was given to species level in a lot of cases, but few had data from all 4 sites. I only included species-level data where the species had data for all 4 sites (so could calculate mean for the 2 native and 2 invaded sites). I then worked up to coarser taxonomic resolutions i.e. genus then family then order, where if I could sum the species level to the genus/family /order level and if each of the 4 sites had a value, then I used this to calculate mean and SD at this taxonomic level. This seemed good balance between keeping as much detail as possible (by including species level data were available) but still being able to include more of the data overall.
